headline: Over one billion people at risk of hearing loss due to loud music –WHO
summarized_story:
Lara AdejoroOver one billion people aged 12 to 35 years risk losing their hearing due to prolonged and excessive exposure to loud music and other recreational sounds, the World Health Organisation has said.
The WHO made the call in a statement issued ahead of the 2022 World Hearing Day, adding that young people are more at risk of hearing loss as a result of loud music because they are more exposed to it.
She added: “The risk is intensified as most audio devices, venues and events do not provide safe listening options and contribute to the risk of hearing loss.
The UN body noted that while exposure to loud sounds causes temporary hearing loss or tinnitus, prolonged or repeated exposure can lead to permanent hearing damage, resulting in irreversible hearing loss.
WHO encourages governments to develop and enforce legislation for safe listening and raise awareness of the risks of hearing loss.

headline: Senate Approves Financial Autonomy for state legislatures, judiciary and LGAs – Nigerian Observer

Out of a total number of 88 Senators registered to vote on the bill, 34 voted in support, and 53 against the bill.

headline: Federal Govt Unveils New Approach To Tackle Adult Illiteracy

The Executive Secretary, while commending President Muhammadu Buhari and Education Minister, Adamu Adamu, for funding of the Adult and Non-Formal education sector, stated that LEEDS will form the antidote to poverty as it has been empirically proven that mere acquisition of basic and post-literacy skills devoid of economic empowerment tools aggravates poverty with its accompanying deleterious socio-economic consequences.
It can be recalled that the federal government recently unveiled a plan to educate about two million non-literate Nigerians annually to enable them uplift their status and enable them contribute to national development.
ADVERTISEMENTThe National Commission for Mass Literacy, Adult and Non-Formal Education was established by Act 17 of June 25, 1990, with a mandate to, among others things, provide basic education to the country’s non-literate adults and youths aged 15 and above through a non-formal approach.
